/docs/definition.iso/639/3/eng: This *default namespace* collects all *terms* and *descriptors* that constitute the *core* of the *data dictionary*.

/docs/description.iso/639/3/eng: This *root namespace* does not have a namespace and its *local* and *global* *identifiers* are *empty*. This means that nobody, except the *curator* of the data dictionary, can *add terms* to *this namespace*. This also means that *global identifiers* *derived* from *this namespace* *begin* with the *separator token*. This namespace can only contain other namespaces.

/docs/definition.iso/639/3/eng: This *namespace* collects all *default* data dictionary *descriptors* for *codes*, *names* and *identifiers*.

/docs/description.iso/639/3/eng:
Both *terms* and *descriptors* will use entries from this namespace.

This namespace *derives* from the *root namespace*, so *nobody*, except the data dictionary curator, can *add terms* to it.

/docs/definition.iso/639/3/eng: This *namespace* collects all *default* data dictionary *descriptors* for *data types*, *formats* and *constraints*.

/docs/description.iso/639/3/eng:
Only  *descriptors* will use entries from this namespace.

This namespace *derives* from the *root namespace*, so *nobody*, except the data dictionary curator, can *add terms* to it.

/docs/definition.iso/639/3/eng: This *namespace* collects all *default* data dictionary *descriptors* for *documentation* and *comments*.

/docs/description.iso/639/3/eng:
Both *terms* and *descriptors* will use entries from this namespace.

This namespace *derives* from the *root namespace*, so *nobody*, except the data dictionary curator, can *add terms* to it.

/docs/definition.iso/639/3/eng: This *namespace* collects all *default* data dictionary *descriptors* for *relationship* and *edge* objects.

/docs/description.iso/639/3/eng: Relationship descriptors are used in *edge* objects, that implement *relationships* between a *source* an *destination* nodes. These fields reference the nodes and the *predicate* of the relationship.

/docs/definition.iso/639/3/eng: This *namespace* collects all *default* data dictionary *controlled vocabularies*.

/docs/description.iso/639/3/eng: This namespace *derives* from the *root namespace*, so *nobody*, except the data dictionary curator, can *add terms* to it.

/docs/definition.iso/639/3/eng: This *namespace* collects all *default* data dictionary *structure* definitions.

/docs/description.iso/639/3/eng: This namespace *derives* from the *root namespace*, so *nobody*, except the data dictionary curator, can *add terms* to it.

/docs/definition.iso/639/3/eng: This *namespace* collects all *default* data dictionary *controlled vocabulary terms* related to *data types* and *management*.

/docs/description.iso/639/3/eng: This namespace *derives* from the *root namespace*, so *nobody*, except the data dictionary curator, can *add terms* to it.
This *controlled vocabulary* lists the *categories* that the *data dictionary* assigns to *values* in terms of *what* the *values represent*.
This term represents a *name* or *hash*, does *not* represent a *quantity* and does not represent a *category*, can take an *infinite number of values*.
This term represents a *category* or *label*, does *not represent* a *quantity* and takes a *finite number of values*, can be *nominal* or *ordinal*.
This term represents a *quantity*, a *discrete* or *continuous* value, it does *not represent a category* and can take an *infinite number of values*, it is by definition *numeric*.

/docs/definition.iso/639/3/eng: Data dictionary data container type classifications.

/docs/description.iso/639/3/eng: This *controlled vocabulary* lists the categories used in the data dictionary to define the *shape* or *container* in which the descriptor *values* are organised.

/docs/definition.iso/639/3/eng: The value is *scalar*, it is not a *collection* or *container*.

/docs/description.iso/639/3/eng: A number or a string is a scalar value.

/docs/definition.iso/639/3/eng: The value is a list of elements.

/docs/description.iso/639/3/eng: A *list* of values of the same  [type](/enum/data/types).

/docs/definition.iso/639/3/eng: The value is a list of unique elements.

/docs/description.iso/639/3/eng: A *list* of *unique* values of the same  [type](/enum/data/types): no value can be repeated.

/docs/definition.iso/639/3/eng: The value is a key/value dictionary.

/docs/description.iso/639/3/eng: A *dictionary* is made of a *key* component and a corresponding *value* component. The key must be a [string](/enum/data/types/string) or a [controlled vocabulary](/enum/data/types/enum) *element*, the value can take any [data type](/data/type).

/docs/definition.iso/639/3/eng: A range of values defined by a minimum and maximum value.

/docs/description.iso/639/3/eng:
The range is implemented as an *array* of *four* values: a *minimum limit*, a [boolean](/enum/data/types/bool) flag indicating whether the minimum limit should be *included* in the range, a *maximum limit* and a [boolean](/enum/data/types/bool) flag indicating whether the maximum limit should be *included* in the range.

The minimum and maximum limit are defined by the descriptor's [data type](/enum/data/types), and it may only be a numeric type, such as [`int`](/enum/data/types/int) and [`float`](/enum/data/types/float).

Either the *minimum* or *maximum* limit may be `null`, in which case it means that the range does not have either a minimum or maximum *limit*. It obviously makes sense if only *one* of the two *limits* is `null`, note that if the limit is `null`, its corresponding [boolean](/enum/data/types/bool) flag should *not* be *considered*.

/docs/examples.iso/639/3/eng:
`[-5, true, 20, false]`: A *discrete* range including `-5` and up to less than `20`.

`[3, false, 20, true]`: A *discrete* range above `3` up to `20` included.

`[null, true, 20, false]`: A *discrete* range below `20`.

`[3, true, null, true]`: A *discrete* range above and including `3`.

`[-5.3, true, 19.85, false]`: A *continuous* range including `-5.3` and up to less than `19.85`.

`[3.0, false, 20.0, true]`: A *continuous* range above `3` up to `20` included.

`[null, true, 20.0, false]`: A *continuous* range below `20`.

`[3.0, true, null, true]`: A *continuous* range above and including `3`.

/docs/description.iso/639/3/eng: This *controlled vocabulary* defines the *data type* of a *descriptor's value*, if the [container](/data/container) is [scalar](/enum/data/containers/scalar), or of the descriptor's *container elements*, if the [container](/data/container) is [dict](/enum/data/containers/dict), [list](/enum/data/containers/list) or [set](/enum/data/containers/set).
The value can be a [boolean](/enum/data/types/bool), [integer](/enum/data/types/int), [floating point number](/enum/data/types/float) or a [string](/enum/data/types/string).
Integer numeric value
Floating point numeric value.
Text encoded in UTF-8 characters.

/docs/definition.iso/639/3/eng: Reference to a data dictionary term.

/docs/description.iso/639/3/eng: The [global identifier](/code/gid) of a term.

/docs/definition.iso/639/3/eng: Reference to a specific database record.

/docs/description.iso/639/3/eng: This type references a *specific record* in the *database*. It represents the *native address* of a specific record *in the database*, if the database in use provides it, or the *primary key* of a record in a predefined *table* or *collection*. This type is generally used in edge records to reference source and destination nodes in a graph.

/docs/definition.iso/639/3/eng: Value representing a precise instant in time.

/docs/description.iso/639/3/eng: *Time-stamp* in the *native format* for the database in use, values of this kind are used to record a *precise moment in time*.

Values of this type must be *elements* of a *controlled vocabulary*, expressed as the term [local](/code/lid) or [global](/code/gid) identifier. Enumerations are *hierarchical*, this means that the [local](/code/lid) identifiers of all elements must be unique.
Values of this type represent an *object* structured as a *hierarchical schema* of *terms*, in which *leaf terms* are *descriptors*.

This *controlled vocabulary* defines the different *data formats* in which a *descriptor's value* could be *encoded*. In general this *applies* to *string* data and requires *custom management* of the data, both in *input* and in *output*.

/docs/definition.iso/639/3/eng: Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) is an XML-based vector image format for two-dimensional graphics with support for interactivity and animation. The SVG specification is an open standard developed by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) since 1999.
Rules and restrictions that apply to the descriptor values.
The value is required, it cannot be omitted or be empty.

/docs/description.iso/639/3/eng: [String](/enum/data/types/string) [data types](/data/type) cannot be *empty*, [list](/enum/data/containers/list), [set](/enum/data/containers/set) and [dictionary](/enum/data/containers/dict) [containers](/data/container) must have at least one element, the value is *not optional*.
Once the value has been *recorded*, it *cannot* be *changed*, this means that after the record has been *inserted*, the value *cannot* be *set*, *modified*, or *removed*.

A *predicate* defines a relationship between a *source* and *destination* node. The relationship is uniquely identified by a *source* node, a *predicate* and a *destination* node. When you create a relationship between two entities, you need to qualify the type of relationship, two related nodes may have many relationships, provided each one has a different predicate. Note that in hierarchical tree structures predicates follow the *many-to-one* direction.

/docs/definition.iso/639/3/eng: The source node is a valid choice of the destination node.

/docs/description.iso/639/3/eng: his predicate is used in enumeration or *controlled vocabulary* graphs. When two nodes are related with this predicate, it means that the *source* node is a controlled vocabulary *element* of the *destination* node. This means that the source node can be used as a *valid choice* when presenting users with an options list.

/docs/definition.iso/639/3/eng: The source node is a property of the destination node.

/docs/description.iso/639/3/eng: This predicate is used in *object* or *schema* graphs. This predicate involves the concept of *property*, a property is a *descriptor*, a term that features a *data type* and defines an entity that has a *well defined value*. The *source* node is a *property* of the *destination* node which can either be a *structure* type, or a [section](/enum/pred/in-section) of a *structure* type. You can think of this predicate as the [enum-of](/enum/pred/enum-of) for data *schemas* or *structures*.

/docs/definition.iso/639/3/eng: The source node is a section of the destination node.

/docs/description.iso/639/3/eng: This predicate involves the concept of *section*, a section is a *category* or *heading* that *groups* a *set* of *choices*. For instance, while the [enumeration](/enum/pred/enum-of) or [property](/enum/pred/property-of) predicates indicates that the source node is either a *valid* controlled vocabulary *choice*, or a *descriptor* belonging to the *destination* node, this predicate would indicate that the source node is to be used as a *container* or *disclosure list*, but not as a valid choice. This predicate is used to *group* controlled vocabulary elements or sets of schema descriptors into sections that will be displayed in the user interface when presenting forms.

/docs/definition.iso/639/3/eng: The source node is a bridge of the destination node.

/docs/description.iso/639/3/eng: This predicate indicates that the *source* node acts as a *bridge* to the *destination* node. This means that the *source* of such relationship should be *hidden* or *skipped* when *traversing* the *path*. Edges with this predicate are found in two scenarios. To allow a *new enumeration root* to *take advantage* of the network belonging to an *existing controlled vocabulary root*, or to *enforce* the *selection* of a *preferred* or *default* element different than the search target.

/docs/examples.iso/639/3/eng:
Suppose you have a controlled vocabulary that is exhaustive and has a large number of elements, you want to create a new controlled vocabulary that shares most, but not all the elements of the first enumeration. You normally would need to duplicate the graph nodes and edges and connect them to the new root. By making the old root a bridge to the new root and by adding the new root to the [path](/rels/path) to all relevant edges, it will appear that all the relevant elements belong directly to the new root.

Suppose you have two controlled vocabularies that classify the same information, but enumeration A is partial, while enumeration B is exhaustive. If you want to enforce the use of enumeration B, even passing through enumeration A, you can connect controlled vocabulary A elements with the bridge predicate and connect the related enumeration B elements wuth the [enumeration](/enum/pred/enum-of) predicate. This way when you search for an element in enumeration A, you will get back the corresponding element of enumeration B.
